abstract.p: Form controls have been introduced to allow attribute values to be edited right into the author area. A form control can be a text field, a check box, a combo box or a pop-up selection window. Aside from these built-in types, you can also provide a custom implementation to handle a specific use case.
To use a form control, the function oxy_editor must be used in the CSS. This function can appear on the content property:
The function signature consists in property name -> property value pairs. For the previous example we have two properties: type with value text and edit with value #text.

These form controls can also be used to edit the text value of an element. Assuming that the text value is edited using a form control, the same value shouldn't be presented in the content. To obtain this behaviour you can use the following rule to hide the text content of an element that will be edited with a form control:

Either than using the generic oxy_editor function, the built-in form controls can also be used though dedicated functions: oxy_textfield, oxy_combobox, oxy_checkbox, oxy_popup, oxy_datePicker and oxy_urlChooser.

section.title: Simple check box editor
section.p: In this example we use a check box form control to edit an attribute with two possible values: On/Off These values are specified in the CSS file, although they could also come from the schema (like in example 2.2):

Note the arguments values and uncheckedValues that give the values for the checked and unchecked check box states. The labels argument gives a user friendly label description that will be associated visually with the checked state.

section.title: Check box with values collected from schema
section.p: In this example we have a check box similar with the one from the previous example except that the values are detected from the schema:
Note that the values and the uncheckedValues arguments are missing:

section.title: A set of multiple check boxes
section.p: In this example we use multiple check boxes to edit a composed attribute value. Depending whether the check box is selected or not a different value is committed.

Note that the values and the uncheckedValues arguments represent an enumeration of comma separated values. The resultSeparator argument is used to compose the attribute value from the states of the check boxes.

section.title: Another set of multiple check boxes
section.p: In this example we will use multiple check boxes just like in the previous example but this time only the selected checkboxes will commit a value:
Note that the uncheckedValues property is missing.

section.title: Combo box with values provided by CSS
section.p: In this example we will use a combo box to edit an attribute value. The possible values are provided from CSS, but these values can be further edited:
Note the values argument that gives the content completion values.

section.title: Combo box with values provided by schema
section.p: In this example we will use a combo box to edit the text value of an element. This time the content completion values are provided from the schema (XML Schema or DTD). Also the combo is not editable in order to enforce only the correct values:
Note the values argument is missing and that the editable argument is false.

section.title: Removing the attribute edited by a combo box
section.p: In order to delete the attribute edited by a combo box one can use an oxy_button next to the oxy_combobox like in the example below:
section.pre: comboBoxWithRemove:before { content: oxy_label(text, "Combobox:", width, 120px, text-align, left) oxy_combobox(edit, "@attribute", editable, false) oxy_button(actionID, 'remove.attribute', color, red, transparent, true); }

section.title: URL chooser form control
section.p: An URL chooser form control allows browsing for a local or remote URL. The selected URL is made relative to the currently edited file:
We also impose a preferred width using the columns argument.

section.title: Pop-up with single selection
section.p: In this example we use a pop-up form control to edit an attribute value of an element. The form control presents a list of possible values of which only one can be selected. The possible values offered by content completion are specified in CSS.

Note the values argument that specifies the content completion values and the selectionMode argument which enforces the selection of a single item. Also the rows argument imposes the number of visible items in the pop-up list (a scroll bar will be used).

section.title: Pop-up with multiple selection
section.p: In this example we will use a pop-up form control to edit a composed attribute value.

Note the values argument that specifies the content completion values. If this argument is missing the values will be taken from the associated schema. The selectionMode argument value is the one that imposes the multiple selection from the form control (as opposed to the previous example). The argument resultSeparator will be used to compose all the selected values into the final value that will be committed.

section.title: Date picker for an xs:date type attribute
section.p: In this example we use a date picker form control to edit an attribute value. The attribute is defined in the schema as having an xs:date type.
section.pre: datePicker:before { content: oxy_label(text, "Date attribute defined in the schema: ", width, 300px) oxy_datePicker( columns, 16, edit, "@attribute") }

section.title: Date picker for an xs:dateTime type attribute
section.p: In this example we will use a date picker form control to edit an attribute value. The attribute is defined in the schema as having an xs:dateTime type.

section.title: Date picker for a generic attribute
section.p: In this example we will use a date picker form control to edit an attribute value. The attribute is defined in the schema as having an xs:string type. The format of the attribute value is defined through the format argument value in the CSS.
Note that the value of format argument must be a valid Java date format.

section.title: Button
section.p: In this example we use a button form control that invokes an action declared in the Author > Actions section of the associated Document Type. When pushed, this button will insert another element, whose values are editable using a pop-up window.
Note the actionID argument that specifies the ID of the action that will be executed.

section.title: Action context
section.p: The action associated with the button form control is executed by default in the context of the element on which it is bound to. If you use the actionContext property you can instead execute it in the current selection context.
Select words and apply styling on them using the small contextual toolbar from above.

section.title: Button Group
section.p: In this example we use a button group form control that triggers a pop-up menu with a set of actions. Each action is defined in the Author > Actions section of the associated Document Type.
Note the actionIDs is a comma separated list of actions to be included in the pop-up menu.

section.title: Text area
section.p: The text area form control can be used to edit the text content of a node. It offers optional syntax highlighting if a content type is specified as an editor property.
The first text area offsers syntax highlight for CSS content and resizes itself to fit its content.
The text area below specifies the rows and column counts, so it has a fixed size and offers syntax highlighting for XML content.
The text edited by the oxy_textArea can contain builtin character entities and the corresponding character will be rendered instead of them.

section.title: Media files
section.p: The media form controls can be used to play media files directly in the editor page.

An audio player is added through the CSS extension function oxy_audio:

section.title: Browser
section.p: This type of form control allows you to integrate HTML pages directly in the document area.
The browser from control can be added through the CSS extension function oxy_browser

section.title: Interacting with the Oxygen Workspace
section.p: From JavaScript you can access the Oxygen API to perform changes in the document, to open resources, etc.
The Javascript loaded inside a browser form control can access the Oxygen environment through these global variables:

li.p: authorAccess - this object is an instance of ro.sync.ecss.extensions.api.AuthorAccess.
contextElement - an instance of ro.sync.ecss.extensions.api.node.AuthorNode. The form control is added over this node.
fcArguments - a java.util.Map implementation with the property name -> property value pairs passed on the form control function.
apiHelper - A helper object for creating Java objects. These objects can afterwards be passed as arguments when calling Oxygen's Java API:

section.p: To log you can use console.log("message to present").

section.title: SVG renderer
section.p: The browser form control can also render dynamic SVGs
